pullRequest.body:
Every complete linear order with well-founded `<` is a successor order.

We also change some `LinearOrder 풤` + `IsWellOrder 풤 (<)` to `LinearOrder 풤` + `WellFoundedLT 풤`. Note that these instances are mathematically equivalent, but the former has redundant assumptions.

---

PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

Pull request successfully merged into master.

  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10449243067/job/28931162465)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10449243067/job/28931162802)

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

```suggestion
  le_of_lt_succ b a hs := by
```

```suggestion
  succ_le_of_lt a b ha := by
```
This doesn't work, unfortunately. I think implicit variables might be the issue.

```suggestion
  succ_le_of_lt {a b} ha := by
```
then

```suggestion
the successor of an element to be the infimum of all larger elements. -/
```

Something I don't understand: Why not just
```suggestion
noncomputable def WellFoundedLT.toSuccOrder [WellFoundedLT 풤] :
    SuccOrder 풤 where
  succ a := if ha : IsMax a then a else WellFounded.min (by simpa ha)
```
so that you don't even have to assume the order is conditionally complete?

The definition with `WellFoundedLT` is a bit weird conceptually. `succ a` would return an entirely arbitrary element covering `a`. But yes, it could be done.

We could even set this definition up in terms of `WellFounded.succ`(which I guess shows it does have some usage). Then I could add a comment on that definition explaining that if your well-order relation is `<`, you should use this instance instead.

Proving `Cardinal.succ_def` would become more annoying though. We would have to add the theorem `WellFounded.succ a = sInf {b | b < a}`, which does require a conditional linear order lattice.

> The definition with `WellFoundedLT` is a bit weird conceptually. `succ a` would return an entirely arbitrary element covering `a`.

But that element is unique! (at least if your order is complete)

Of course, the definition is well-behaved if you enforce that additional restriction. In an order that isn't complete, this instance would have little computational value. For instance, the successor of `{칒}` under `ZFSet` membership could be either of `{칒, {칒}}` or `{{칒}}` with no way to tell.

By the way, I'm finding `WellFounded.succ` annoying to work with. The definition cases on whether `갞 b, r a b` which is a different (albeit equivalent) spelling to `춻 IsMax a`. So this might be yet another reason to ditch that definition.

I've just discovered a pretty big issue: this definition doesn't work on partial orders! Consider the partial order `a, b < c`. Then `a < succ b` but `춻 a 곣 b`.

A linear order with well-founded `<` is always a conditionally complete linear order, so we would gain no generality (and some annoyance) by changing the definition like this.

> A linear order with well-founded `<` is always a conditionally complete linear order, so we would gain no generality (and some annoyance)

Which spelling does mathlib use the most?

We have some API for the latter, see e.g. [`csInf_mem`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/ConditionallyCompleteLattice/Basic.html#csInf_mem) (note that this PR generalizes the `IsWellOrder` assumption to `WellFoundedLT`). I don't think we have any for the former, except for the [IsWellOrderLimitElement](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/IsWellOrderLimitElement.html) file I've complained about for this exact reason and others (see my comment on #11584).

In any case, we should always prefer the latter spelling, as it gives us access to `Inf` and `Sup` notation and all the lemmas that exist for it.

Okay, I agree

maintainer merge
